“Now, Credo,â€ Sanctus whispered sweetly, the pad of his thumb brushing Credoâ€™s gloved hand. The action made his skin crawl, but he watched Sanctus carefully. He swallowed down his resentment, finally speaking up.
â€œYes, your Holiness?â€
â€œYou know what happens to those who cannot behave well with the Order?â€ Credo stared into his lap for a long time before he snapped his head up attentively.
â€œYes your Holiness, I do.â€
When Credo had finally entered his home it had been late. Credo rested his head at the door, feeling the heavy weight of the information Sanctus shared in private with him.
All this talk of a Savior from Sanctus was all he was thinking about. Sanctus had promised many things during this secret meeting, but Credo began to wonder if it was all the fantasy of a senile old man. Nevertheless, Credo was fascinated. Was it possible to become an angel?
He trudged up the steps slowly as he tugged open his uniform. A bottle of brandy and schematics of Blanco Angelo, a special guardian class that would be constructed to protect the city were littered about the messy floor of his study. It was his space of Zen, a place he could go to when things were out of control. Right now he wanted to tug off his strapped boots, and fall asleep on the divan in that room. Tonight’s choice of poison would be Cognac Brandy, a twenty-year old Delamain Pale & Dry that was given to him as a gift when he ascended the ranks to Commander.
His household was a respectively quiet place. Kyrie was hardly ever here now, constantly at the church to pray and sing and do whatever young girls her age did. Despite his beloved sisterâ€™s absence, Credo enjoyed the peace and quiet when he could. He wasn’t one for social interactions, and enjoyed being alone. Deep into his thirties, Credo had learned to befriend his loneliness. The job had no room for much of anything else. The rest was simply chaos.
Entering his study (which was adjacent to the master bedroom) Credo tossed his uniform top across the divan, settling in an old wooden chair with a sigh. There were simple pleasures in life, and this chair was certainly one of them. The crystal snifter of brandy sat untouched at the messy desk beside him as he contemplated drinking to boost his denial at what was going on. It was always a choice he had no problem making.
Until now.
Credo was always known to be self-sufficient. Since the time his parents passed away, heâ€™d stepped up to take care of his little sister, Kyrie. Things had been very hard at firstâ€”he was only fifteen years old when Sanctus took power of the Order.
Credoâ€™s brow creased. Those times were well beyond him, now.
â€œDo you know what your name means, my son?â€
â€œNo, your Holiness, I do not.â€
â€œIt is a statement or belief; a creed. Remember to walk uprightly in this world, my dearest Credo.â€
The soft sound of Sanctusâ€™ voice ebbed away into the back of Credoâ€™s mind as his memory faded away. Credo reached for the snifter without hesitation to pour himself a glass. It had been years since heâ€™d remembered that conversation. It was one of the turning points to his career as an acolyte to the order, and a pivotal moment into adulthood. He had no idea he would become a target of Sanctus, nor become his right hand.
The things heâ€™d done to get there haunted himâ€”foolish, stupid things.
â€˜I did it for Kyrie, for our future.â€™ But, deep down that was never the real reason. The heat built up in his chest and stomach as he leaned back with his legs spread. I could use one more glass, Credo rationalized as he poured another. Just as he was about to take a sip, a soft rap at his door caused him to reach for his sword on impulse, but eased when he saw Neroâ€™s white head poke through.
‘Damn. Just like Nero to interrupt my plans of self-pity.’
â€œHowâ€™d you get in here?â€ Credo barked; Nero barely took into account how grumpy Credo was. Perhaps he was so used to Credoâ€™s abrasive behavior, or was simply unaffected by it.
â€œKyrie gave me the key.â€ Neroâ€™s brow rose in amusement at Credoâ€™s almost confused glare.
â€œYou and my sister have been awfully close. Did you steal it off of her?â€ Credo sneered as he downed his glass. Nero leaned in the doorway, arms crossed.
â€œI just pointed out that she gaveâ€”meâ€”theâ€”key.â€ Nero reiterated, rolling his eyes. â€œYouâ€™re drinking this late, again huh?â€
â€œGo away, Nero.â€ Credo grunted, not amused by Neroâ€™s game of twenty-one questions. But the boy strode into the room regardless as an open act of invading his privacy.
‘Nero, be damned.’
Not anyone could be in this room. Kyrie wasnâ€™t even allowed in here. What made Nero think he was more deserving? Credo sat back and reached for the glass grumpily.
“He has no sense of self-control, Credo. You know what happens to those whoâ€™re unruly, donâ€™t you?â€™” The soft titter of Sanctusâ€™ laughter echoed at the back of his mind. The hair on Credoâ€™s neck stood on end. Sanctus could not get a hold of Nero. Credo felt ill at ease at the idea. He was sure Nero knew nothing of those “initiations” the Order did in secrecy. Credo wanted to keep it that way. He would protect Nero for as long as he could. Not that he really needed it, now that he was a capable fighter for the Order. In fact, perhaps he was one of the best. His attitude on the other handâ€¦
â€œI spoke with his Holiness, today.â€ Credo let out tersely as Nero tumbled haphazardly into the divan. Credo watched him with furrowed brows as Neroâ€™s muddied boots draped over one of the arms. Credo rubbed the bridge of his nose as he barreled on.
â€œAbout?â€ Nero dug a finger in his ear. Credo seemed affronted by the act.
â€œYour inability to cooperate with the Order, it seems.â€
â€œLook, itâ€™s not my fault those assholes have a problem with how I do things. It gets the freaking job done. Case closed.â€ Nero made hand gestures as if to wipe his hands of something, tossing his hair out from his face. Credoâ€™s eyes narrowed before downing another glass.
â€œI get that you are doing all this to prove something. But, donâ€™t be an idiot.â€ By the fifth cup, Credo could feel the velvety burn of the amber liquid coat his insides. He felt right where he needed to be, almost ready to ignore Neroâ€™s presence.
â€œGonna give me a taste of that?â€
Credo had almost forgotten about Nero for a moment, swiveling slowly in his creaky wooden chair. Credo regarded Neroâ€™s crouched sitting position on the couch. The boy was staring at him openly with that curious gaze of his.
Credo curled his lip. Just what was he looking at, anyway? Credoâ€™s eyes wandered lazily over Neroâ€™s facial features. Heâ€™d grown so much in these last two years alone. Nero had always been quite the pipsqueak in his younger years, constantly following the older male about. Heâ€™d been so taken to Credo as a child. It was borderline ridiculous how much time theyâ€™d spent together. In some ways Credo was like the brotherly figure Nero enjoyed looking up to. The boy made no secret about it. Credo never wanted to admit it, but Nero looking up to him was an experience he did not like at first. The same snot-nosed brat heâ€™d encountered on those orphanage steps was no longer a boy. Nero was fast becoming a man. Unable to hold their gaze, the older man averted his eyes elsewhere.
â€œAren’t you too young to be drinking this? Don’t ask again.â€ Credo chuffed.
â€œIâ€™m not a little kid anymore, Credo.â€Credo pausing at Neroâ€™s intense gaze. The older man looked away again, the awkward silence filling the space between them. It was true that he was no longer a child. Credo also understood the rift between them was due to them being generations apart. He just didn’t understand teenagers nowadays. He wondered if he had been this moody and insufferable at that age.
Credo’s stomach coiled. His childhood had not been the best. Perhaps he had poor judgement in what kids were “up to” these days. Maybe he was just getting old.
â€œI suppose you arenâ€™t.â€ Credo finally said as he reached for another glass atop the shelf, pouring the glass to the brim. Neroâ€™s ears perked. Credo pretended he didnâ€™t see that as he poured the glass. Surely there was a law out there somewhere he was breaking.
Story of my life, Credo thought sourly.
The soft shuffle of Neroâ€™s leather-strapped boots behind Credo made his shoulders tense. Nero sat at the edge of the desk, plucking the glass from Credoâ€™s hand, their fingers touching. Credo looked up slowly to watch Nero drink down the amber liquid, a trail of liquor dripping down his throat. Nero watched Credo reach for the snifter, stopping the older man from getting it. There was an almost teasing smile about that young face of hisâ€”Credo gave him a suspicious glance.
â€œWhy are you here, anyway?â€ Credo asked. He wasnâ€™t sure why he didnâ€™t ask sooner.
Nero instantly seemed withdrawn, cocking his head to the side to shrug nonchalantly. â€œI donâ€™t know, to be honest. I hoped youâ€™d be here, so I came up.â€
He came for him? Credo shifted in his chair, slightly guarded by Neroâ€™s confession. Working for the order had kept Credo pre-occupied most days. There was a time when they hardly saw one another, both of them pre-occupying themselves with the swarms of demons occupying the outskirts of Fortuna City. His cheeks colored a bit, clearing his throat. It had been quite some time since they even sat in the same room together. To do so now was more uncomfortable than anything. He hardly recognized the young man sitting just a hairâ€™s breadth away from him.
â€œI suppose Iâ€™m gladâ€¦ you came.â€ Credo leaned back into the chair, placing his glass down.
â€œYou do?â€ Nero sounded genuinely surprised, his cheeks tinged pink. Was that hope heâ€™d seen? Credo decided not to look at his face. It was nothing to be excited about, honestly. He didnâ€™t know why Nero had to act soâ€¦ he didnâ€™t know how to describe it, really.
â€œWell, I meanâ€”â€œ Had that been uncertainty in the boyâ€™s eyes? â€œErrâ€¦ never mind.â€ Credo watched him do his trademark nose-scratch. He found himself a bit irritated.
Yes, it was definitely time for Nero to leave.
â€œItâ€™s time for you to go.â€
â€œAw, câ€™mon Credo!â€ Neroâ€™s head shot up, standing up to lean on the arm-rests to Credoâ€™s chair, barring his way from escape. The older man let out a sound, curling his lip at Neroâ€™s closeness. Credo gripped into the table. Something about this was wrong.
â€œYouâ€™re making me uncomfortable by just being here, so if you donâ€™t mindâ€”â€ Credo let out, clasping his hand over his mouth as soon as it left him. He had way too much to drink, deciding upon blaming the copious amounts of brandy heâ€™d devoured for its effects. Neroâ€™s eyes lowered as he moved closer until they inhaled each otherâ€™s exhales. Neroâ€™s pink, parted lips were in Credoâ€™s vision.
Wait a fucking minute. What is happening here, exactly?
â€œCredo, Iâ€”â€ Credoâ€™s eyes widened, glued to his chair as Nero bit his lower lip. The sound of the door closing downstairs sent Credo rushing out of the chair. Nero gave a soft curse.
â€œKyrieâ€™s here.â€ Credo whispered out.
â€œLet her come, then?â€ Credo heard from behind him. The older man whipped around to stare at the boy, brows furrowed.
â€œYou’re the one who said she never comes up here!â€ Nero whispered harshly, his cheeks red. The boyâ€™s cheeks lit up brighter than a Christmas tree at Credoâ€™s reprimanding glare.
â€œYes, butâ€”â€œ The hamster wheel in his mind was finally beginning to turn. This was probably the first time in a long time since heâ€™d seen Nero embarrassed with himself. It still reminded him that Nero was still so very young. Way too young.
‘Too young forâ€¦ stop it.’
The noises died away, both of them standing at the door as if they’d committed murder, uncertain as to why they were both hiding like mice in an attic.
What was Nero going to say back then had they not been interrupted? Later on the commander pondered on it but decided to let it go. Deep down, he didnâ€™t want to know. It was just better if Nero did him a favor and kept his mouth shut. Another glass of brandy would help douse his brain free of whatever odd and guilty feeling he had about their little interaction.
He hoped, anyway.
summary:
Chapter One â€œYou called to see me, your Holiness?â€
Sanctus drew a pale, long-fingered hand towards Credo as he signaled him to sit down beside him. Agnus peered back at Credo with contempt, his ridiculous monocle glinting as he did so.
“Ah, Credo. I was just leaving.” Agnus decided to say a little too loudly. “Your excellency.” He bowed dramatically as he exited the room.
Despite several attempts to take his place, Credo was almost certain Sanctus would never sway for the likes of Agnus.
